case_vignette: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. He also has had a loss of sensitivity around his buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Neurologic examination shows reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; the right side is normal. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

I've been having sharp, stabbing pain in my lower back that spreads to the back of my left leg, and I've lost some feeling around my buttocks and inner thighs. I'm also having more trouble urinating lately.

Final Diagnosis: Sciatica or Lumbar Radiculopathy.

(Note: This diagnosis is based on the provided symptoms and further evaluation, including imaging studies or electromyography, may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other conditions.)

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having sharp, stabbing pain in my lower back that shoots down to the back of my left leg, and over the past week, I've also been having more difficulty when I try to urinate.
Is this pain constant or does it come and go? And do you have any history of diabetes or multiple sclerosis?
The pain has been there for two weeks, and no, I don't have diabetes or multiple sclerosis.
Have you ever experienced any numbness or tingling in the same leg as the pain? And do you have a history of heart disease or high blood pressure?
Yes, I've lost some feeling around my buttocks and inner thighs, but no, I don't have heart disease or high blood pressure.
Based on your symptoms, have you ever had any previous episodes like this? And do you smoke or have you been exposed to heavy metals in your work environment?
No, this is the first time I've had symptoms like this, and I haven't been exposed to heavy metals, nor do I smoke.

Given your symptoms, have you had any recent falls or injuries? And do you have a family history of any neurological conditions?

**Final Diagnosis:** Sciatica with possible disc herniation.
